metadata.title: A Formal Theory of Commonsense Psychology: How People Think People Think
metadata.authors: Andrew S. Gordon and Jerry R. Hobbs
metadata.description: Chapter 38 axioms covering planning processes from instantiation to scratch planning, process control, subprocesses, obstacles, and candidate plan selection
metadata.notation: First-order logic with reified planning activities, process control, and plan construction operations

axioms.title: Definition of planningByInstantiating
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s) (iff (planningByInstantiating e a g s) (and (planning e a g s) (forall (p1 p2) (if (successiveElts p1 p2 s) (planInstance p2 p1))))))
axioms.english: The only way we get from one plan to the next is instantiating entity and eventuality types in the earlier plan. This kind of planning is seen when we engage in near habitual action of giving a waiter our order in a restaurant, where we are taking the general restaurant-ordering script and instantiating it with this waiter and the items on this menu.

axioms.title: Definition of planningFromScratch
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s) (iff (planningFromScratch e a g s) (and (planning e a g s) (forall (e0 p1 p2 s1 s2 r1 r2) (if (and (successiveElts' e0 p1 p2 s) (eventualitiesOf s1 p1) (eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (relationsOf r1 p1)(relationsOf r2 p2)) (exists (e1 e2 r r0 e3) (and (member e1 s1)(addElt s2 s1 e2) (causallyInvolved' r e2 e1) (subgoal' r0 e2 e1) (addElt r2 r1 r0)(believe' e3 a r) (cause e3 e0))))))))
axioms.english: Planning from scratch where we are not instantiating a well-worn script. Rather we are mining our knowledge of what causes what and using basic planning axioms to achieve our goal. p2 is constructed from p1 by adding a subgoal e2 to p1, on the basis of a belief e3 in r that e2 is causally involved in e1.

axioms.title: Definition of singleGoalPlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s) (iff (singleGoalPlanning e a g s) (and (planning e a g s) (not (exists (g1 g2) (and' g g1 g2))))))
axioms.english: People can plan to achieve single goals.

axioms.title: Definition of multipleGoalPlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s) (iff (multipleGoalPlanning e a g s) (and (planning e a g s) (exists (g1 g2) (and' g g1 g2)))))
axioms.english: People can plan to achieve multiple goals.

axioms.title: Definition of suspendPlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (a e) (iff (suspendPlanning a e) (exists (g s t) (and (suspend a e t)(Now t)(planning e a g s)))))
axioms.english: People can suspend a planning process, as seen in the expressions 'hold off on the details' and 'put aside the plan.'

axioms.title: Definition of resumePlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (a e) (iff (resumePlanning a e) (exists (g s t) (and (resume a e t)(Now t)(planning e a g s)))))
axioms.english: People can resume working on a plan after they have suspended the planning process, as seen in the expressions 'finish the plan' and 'take up the plan again.'

axioms.title: Definition of abortPlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (a e) (iff (abortPlanning a e) (exists (g s t) (and (abort a e t)(Now t)(planning e a g s)))))
axioms.english: People can decide to abandon a planning process, as in 'stop planning' and 'give up on the plan.'

axioms.title: Definition of replan
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 a p g) (iff (replan' e1 a p g) (exists (e s t)(and (planning e a g s)(restart' e1 a e t)(Now t)))))
axioms.english: The planning process can be restarted, as seen in 'start from scratch,' 'back to the drawing board' and 'try a different approach.'

axioms.title: Definition of replanSubplan
axioms.fol: (forall (e1 a p1 p g) (iff (replanSubplan' e1 a p1 p g) (exists (g1) (and (replan' e1 a p1 g1)(plan p a g)(plan p1 a g1) (subgoal g1 g)))))
axioms.english: Since a subplan of a plan, to achieve a subgoal, is itself a plan, this can also be restarted. We see this in the phrases 'patch the plan,' 'fix part of the plan,' and 'rework a step.'

axioms.title: Definition of specifyPlan
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (specifyPlan e a g s p1 p2) (planInstancePlus p2 p1))))
axioms.english: During planning, people can add detail to a plan in development, as seen in the expressions 'flesh out the details' and 'be specific about the plan.' For example, we may have a plan to eat at McDonald's. When we walk into McDonald's, we make our plan more specific by choosing a specific register.

axioms.title: Definition of addSubplan
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (addSubplan e a g s p1 p2) (exists (s1 s2 s3 g1 p3) (and (eventualitiesOf s1 p1)(eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (setdiff s3 s2 s1)(subgoalIn g1 p1) (plan p3 a g1)(eventualitiesOf s3 p3) (forall (g2) (if (member g2 s3)(subgoalIn g2 p3))))))))
axioms.english: People can add a subplan to a plan, as in the expressions 'add a step,' 'addendum to the plan,' and 'put a part in the plan.' Agent a has moved from plan p1 to the next plan p2 by adding a subplan (p3) to achieve a subgoal (g1) of g.

axioms.title: Definition of removeSubplan
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (removeSubplan e a g s p1 p2) (exists (s1 s2 s3 g1 p3) (and (eventualitiesOf s1 p1)(eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (setdiff s3 s1 s2)(subgoalIn g1 p2) (plan p3 a g1)(eventualitiesOf s3 p3) (forall (g2) (if (member g2 s3) (subgoalIn g2 p3))))))))
axioms.english: During planning people can remove a subplan from the plan in development, as in the expressions 'remove a step' and 'simplify the plan.' This definition is like that for addSubplan, but with the arguments of setdiff reversed.

axioms.title: Definition of identifyPrecondition
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (identifyPrecondition e a g s p1 p2) (exists (s1 s2 s3 g1 g2) (and (eventualitiesOf s1 p1)(eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (setdiff s3 s2 s1)(member g1 s1)(member g2 s3) (enable g2 g1))))))
axioms.english: During planning, people can notice that the goal or a subgoal has a precondition, as in 'realize we first need to' and 'see a necessary step.' g2 is the new subgoal of g1 that was realized to be a precondition of g1 in p1.

axioms.title: Definition of selectSubplan
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (selectSubplan e a g s p1 p2) (exists (s1 s2 e0 e1 e2) (and (eventualitiesOf s1 p1)(eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (or' e0 e1 e2) (or (replaceElt s2 s1 e0 e1) (replaceElt s2 s1 e0 e2)))))))
axioms.english: During planning, people often make selections among alternative subplans. That is, they replace a disjunction with one of its disjuncts. This is seen in the expressions 'choose a step' and 'select an action.' e0 is a disjunction of eventualities e1 and e2, and the difference between successive plans is that e0 is replaced by e1 or e2.

axioms.title: Definition of orderSubplans
axioms.fol: (forall (e a g s p1 p2) (if (and (planning e a g s)(successiveElts p1 p2 s)) (iff (orderSubplans e a g s p1 p2) (exists (s1 s2 s3 g1 g2 e0) (and (eventualitiesOf s1 p1)(eventualitiesOf s2 p2) (setdiff s3 s2 s1)(member g1 s1)(member g2 s1) (before' e0 g1 g2)(member e0 s3))))))
axioms.english: People often decide during planning what order they should achieve the subgoals in, as seen in the expressions 'first things first' and 'figure out the order.' This amounts to adding temporal detail, that is, a before relation. g1 and g2 are subgoals in plan p1 and what is new in plan p2 is the before relation between them.

axioms.title: Definition of obstacle
axioms.fol: (forall (x a g) (iff (obstacle x a g) (exists (e e1) (and (or (cause x e)(and (arg* x e1)(cause e1 e))) (not' e g)(goal g a)))))
axioms.english: An obstacle is something that causes a goal not to occur. Other words for this are 'barrier,' 'impediment,' and 'impasse.' Entity x is an obstacle to agent a's achieving goal g. It can either be x itself or one of its properties e1 that can cause the goal not to occur.

axioms.title: Definition of overcomeObstacle
axioms.fol: (forall (a x g) (iff (overcomeObstacle a x g) (exists (e0 e) (and (obstacle' e0 x a g)(cause a e)(not' e e0) (enable e g)))))
axioms.english: To overcome an obstacle is to cause it not to occur in a way that is consistent with the goal being achieved. Essentially, the elimination of an obstacle is the satisfaction of a precondition. The agent causes the obstacle not to exist as an obstacle.

axioms.title: Definition of planningProblem
axioms.fol: (forall (x a p g) (iff (planningProblem x a p g) (exists (e) (and (obstacle x a g)(overcomeObstacle' e a x g) (plan p a g)(subgoalIn e p)))))
axioms.english: People see these obstacles as problems that must be overcome in their plans. The concept is exemplified in language in 'challenge,' 'dilemma,' 'sticky situation,' and 'something must be done.'

axioms.title: Planning option from obstacle overcoming
axioms.fol: (forall (e p a x g e1) (if (and (plan p a g)(planningProblem x a p g) (overcomeObstacle' e a x g)) (planningOption e p)))
axioms.english: One kind of planning option is the overcoming of an obstacle.

axioms.title: Definition of candidatePlan
axioms.fol: (forall (p a g) (iff (candidatePlan p a g) (exists (e s c t) (and (planning e a g s)(member p s)(inFocus p a) (executable p a c t)(Now t)))))
axioms.english: A candidate plan is a plan that the agent has in focus and is executable now with respect to a set c of constraints. An agent may construct several possible plans to achieve a goal, and then must select among these candidate plans for a plan to execute.

axioms.title: Definition of successfulPlanning
axioms.fol: (forall (a p g) (iff (successfulPlanning e a p g) (exists (e1 s) (and (planning e a g s)(cause e e1) (candidatePlan' e1 p a g)))))
axioms.english: Agents can successfully construct a plan to achieve a goal.

axioms.title: Definition of planningFailure
axioms.fol: (forall (a p g) (iff (planningFailure e a g) (and (planning e a g s) (not (exists (p) (and (member p s)(candidatePlan p a g)))))))
axioms.english: Agents can fail to construct a plan to achieve a goal.

axioms.title: Definition of assessPlan
axioms.fol: (forall (a p g d) (iff (assessPlan a p g d) (exists (e e1) (and (cause' e p g)(gbel' e1 a e d)(changeTo e1)))))
axioms.english: Agents can assess candidate plans to determine which are most likely to achieve the goal. To assess a plan is to come to a belief about how certain the plan is to achieve the goal. Agent a assesses plan p for achieving goal g and has degree of belief d in its success.

axioms.title: Definition of selectCandidatePlan
axioms.fol: (forall (a p g) (iff (selectCandidatePlan a p g) (exists (d0) (and (assessPlan a p g d0) (forall (p1 d1) (if (and (candidatePlan p1 a g) (assessPlan a p1 g d1)) (leq d1 d0))) (decideTo a p)))))
axioms.english: When they behave rationally, agents select from among the candidate plans the plan that is assessed to be the most likely to succeed.

axioms.title: Selected plan scheduling
axioms.fol: (forall (a p1 g) (if (selectCandidatePlan a p1 g) (exists (p2) (schedulePlan a p1 p2))))
axioms.english: A plan that is selected is scheduled, that is, is assigned a time to be executed. Agent a adds a schedule to plan p1, yielding plan p2.

axioms.title: Non-selected candidate exclusion
axioms.fol: (forall (p p1 a g) (if (and (candidatePlan p a g)(candidatePlan p1 a g)(nequal p p1) (decideTo a p)) (not (decideTo a p1))))
axioms.english: Candidate plans that are not selected will not be executed.

conversion_notes.reified_predicates: Extensive use of primed predicates for planning processes and causal relations: successiveElts', causallyInvolved', subgoal', believe', restart', replan', obstacle', overcomeObstacle', candidatePlan', cause', gbel', before', or', not'
conversion_notes.defeasible_reasoning: No axioms use (etc) condition - all planning construction processes are strict logical definitions
conversion_notes.planning_process_control: Comprehensive framework for suspend/resume/abort/restart operations with temporal anchoring
conversion_notes.plan_construction_operations: Systematic treatment of plan development moves: specify, add/remove subplans, identify preconditions, select alternatives, order subgoals
conversion_notes.cross_references: Heavy integration with basic planning theory (Chapter 36), process control operations, and forward references to scheduling (Chapter 42) and execution control (Chapter 45)
conversion_notes.obstacle_framework: Complete treatment of obstacles as planning problems requiring overcoming through precondition satisfaction
conversion_notes.candidate_selection: Rational plan selection based on assessment and belief degrees with scheduling integration
conversion_notes.complex_quantification: Multiple axioms with complex nested quantification especially in plan construction operations and candidate selection

file_format_notes.logical_structure: Mix of simple definitions and complex nested quantification, especially in planningFromScratch, addSubplan/removeSubplan, and selectCandidatePlan
file_format_notes.predicate_consistency: Consistent use of planning terminology with clear semantic distinctions between construction operations
file_format_notes.defeasibility_markers: No defeasible rules - all axioms are strict logical definitions or implications
file_format_notes.reification_patterns: Systematic reification of planning activities, causal relations, and temporal operations
file_format_notes.process_integration: Sophisticated integration of planning processes with general process control operations
